text: my name is Robert nickelsburg I am a
photojournalist Afghanistan a distant
war covers my time in Afghanistan from
1988 to 2013 once the Soviet Army
withdrew created a bit of a political
vacuum in the region civil war began
almost on the second day of the capture
of Kabul I tried to approach it as an
Afghan would on a regular daily basis
going out of their door getting in their
car going to work or jumping on a bus
what would happen you come across a
rocket attack a tank would collide into
a building downtown was a frontline and
often we didn't make it home at night
we'd have to just stay wherever we ended
up five o'clock curfew so it was always
on a wing in a prayer that material got
out it became very challenging and often
editors back in New York would say it's
not worth it for us and it forever
remained a distant story
not just a distant war
if you were to talk to a 22 year old
University student all they've known is
disruption and violence but they're now
much more interconnected with the
internet cell phones social media
they're aware of alternative ways of
living once it became known in 2011 that
Obama wanted to leave the ending becomes
clear for everybody and we could see by
looking backwards as we call 20/20
hindsight and that civil war could begin
again if we don't remain there who's
going to referee who's going to be sort
of the traffic cop to try to maintain
some kind of peace and neutrality the
book is a warning that care needs to be
taken or history will repeat itself
